results.title: An Interview with Douglas Margetts
results.creator_credit: Douglas Margetts and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Douglas Margetts served as part of the Australian 6th Division Signals and served in the Middle East and New Guinea in World War II. He relates his experiences as part of “In our words”, a Digital Storytelling workshop for Victorian war veterans.
results.description: Douglas Margetts served as part of the Australian 6th Division Signals and served in the Middle East and New Guinea in World War II. He relates his experiences as part of “In our words”, a Digital Storytelling workshop for Victorian war veterans.

results.title: An interview with Cyril Sayles
results.brief_description: At the age of 16, Cyril Sayles, not wanting to continue his manual labour in the mines, decided to join the army. Having lied about his age, he had a special made uniform and was off to fight the Germans in World War II. Cyril humorously shares his story of strength and courage, through his battle and imprisonment during the war.
results.description: At the age of 16, Cyril Sayles, not wanting to continue his manual labour in the mines, decided to join the army. Having lied about his age, he had a special made uniform and was off to fight the Germans in World War II. Cyril humorously shares his story of strength and courage, through his battle and imprisonment during the war.
description_for_label: At the age of 16, Cyril Sayles, not wanting to continue his manual labour in the mines, decided to join the army. Having lied about his age, he had a special made uniform and was off to fight the Germans in World War II. Cyril humorously shares his story of strength and courage, through his battle and imprisonment during the war.

results.title: An Interview with Colin Bannister
results.brief_description: In 1950, Colin Bannister sailed from Syndey to Singapore to defend the Malayan Government against an uprising in what was called ‘The Malayan Emergency’. Bannister’s time in Malaya has taught him about power and the important things in life.
results.description: In 1950, Colin Bannister sailed from Syndey to Singapore to defend the Malayan Government against an uprising in what was called ‘The Malayan Emergency’. Bannister’s time in Malaya has taught him about power and the important things in life.

results.title: An Interview with Brigadier Keith Rossi
results.brief_description: Brigadier Keith Rossi went to join up but needed to lie about his age to do so. He tells of his time in the army with humour, capturing the cameraderie that helped alleviate the horror of war. In his time serving, he went from the Middle East, to New Guinea and, later, Vietnam, from Private to Brigadier.
results.description: Brigadier Keith Rossi went to join up but needed to lie about his age to do so. He tells of his time in the army with humour, capturing the cameraderie that helped alleviate the horror of war. In his time serving, he went from the Middle East, to New Guinea and, later, Vietnam, from Private to Brigadier.
description_for_label: Brigadier Keith Rossi went to join up but needed to lie about his age to do so. He tells of his time in the army with humour, capturing the cameraderie that helped alleviate the horror of war. In his time serving, he went from the Middle East, to New Guinea and, later, Vietnam, from Private to Brigadier.

results.title: An Interview with Brigadier John P.A. Deighton
results.brief_description: John Deighton admits that at 18, everyone believes that they are bulletproof but the adventure of war stops when people start dying. He believes that the instant replay effect and the televisation of the Vietnam War was a factor in its unpopularity. He remembers the poor treatment Vietnam vets received on their return and how unfair it was as they were just doing their job.
results.title_for_label: An Interview with Brigadier John P.A. Deighton
results.description: John Deighton admits that at 18, everyone believes that they are bulletproof but the adventure of war stops when people start dying. He believes that the instant replay effect and the televisation of the Vietnam War was a factor in its unpopularity. He remembers the poor treatment Vietnam vets received on their return and how unfair it was as they were just doing their job.
description_for_label: John Deighton admits that at 18, everyone believes that they are bulletproof but the adventure of war stops when people start dying. He believes that the instant replay effect and the televisation of the Vietnam War was a factor in its unpopularity. He remembers the poor treatment Vietnam vets received on their return and how unfair it was as they were just doing their job.

results.title: An Interview with Billie Lindsay
results.brief_description: Billie had just gone through training as a nurse when she was whisked away to war. She tells how she was immediately signed up while waiting for a friend, her time in Malaya and considers the way we look at war today and how her time in the army stood her in good stead later on in life.
results.description: Billie had just gone through training as a nurse when she was whisked away to war. She tells how she was immediately signed up while waiting for a friend, her time in Malaya and considers the way we look at war today and how her time in the army stood her in good stead later on in life.
description_for_label: Billie had just gone through training as a nurse when she was whisked away to war. She tells how she was immediately signed up while waiting for a friend, her time in Malaya and considers the way we look at war today and how her time in the army stood her in good stead later on in life.

results.title: An Interview with Bill Saunders
results.creator_credit: Bill Saunders and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Bill Saunders joined the Airforce with his brother when both were called up in 1941. He shares stories from this time, about his training and posting in Europe as a pilot during World War II. In his time, he flew Tigermoths and the Ansons.
results.description: Bill Saunders joined the Airforce with his brother when both were called up in 1941. He shares stories from this time, about his training and posting in Europe as a pilot during World War II. In his time, he flew Tigermoths and the Ansons.

results.title: An Interview with Arthur Harridge
results.brief_description: Even though Arthur Harridge believes each service being as important as the other, he was primarily an airforce man. He tells of leaving his home and loved ones aboard the Mariposa, bound for the United States and then Europe, where he experienced the horrors of war first hand. An emotional account of the horrors of war, the things that kept the soldiers going returning home and trying to forget.
results.description: Even though Arthur Harridge believes each service being as important as the other, he was primarily an airforce man. He tells of leaving his home and loved ones aboard the Mariposa, bound for the United States and then Europe, where he experienced the horrors of war first hand. An emotional account of the horrors of war, the things that kept the soldiers going returning home and trying to forget.

He tells of leaving his home and loved ones aboard the Mariposa, bound for the United States and then Europe, where he experienced the horrors of war first hand. An emotional account of the horrors of war, the things that kept the soldiers going returning home and trying to forget.

results.title: An Interview with Allan Couper
results.creator_credit: Allan Couper and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Allan Couper is a Victorian World War II veteran. He served as a pilot in Europe as part of the Bomber Squadron. As part of the Digital Storytelling project “In our words”, Allan relates his experiences of fighting in Europe during the war.
results.description: Allan Couper is a Victorian World War II veteran. He served as a pilot in Europe as part of the Bomber Squadron. As part of the Digital Storytelling project “In our words”, Allan relates his experiences of fighting in Europe during the war.

results.title: An Interview with Alfred Maskell
results.brief_description: Alfred Maskell just wanted to see the world. In 1941, he joined the Australian army and was sent to Malaya. By the time he got there, it was clear the Australian forces were up against it, fighting a strong enemy with weaponry from the previous World War. By the end of the year they were captured by the Japanese and forced to perform many unsavoury tasks, from burying Chinese civilians to working on the Thai-Burma railway and, finally, in Japan where he stayed till the war ended. This is a story of the brutality that many prisoners of war suffered during World War 2.
